title: When you trade in a guitar, does the guitar center give you cash or in store value to trade for another guitar? - Quora

response.answer_text: You shouldn’t “trade in” a guitar while you’re buying another instrument. You should make the best deal you can to buy the one you want. A typical music store will accept used instruments to resell either on consignment, or they may offer to buy an instrument outright. “Trading in” your old guitar while buying a new one is the same as the store buying it outright. When they do this, they are taking the risk and spending cash (or effectively spending cash by taking the amount off the price they are getting for your new instrument) while they have to keep the trade-in in stock and wait till someone wants it, and hope it will sell at the price they paid for it. So they typically will pay you about 50% of what they hope they can sell it for later. Some stores do a lot of consignment sales, some very few. When I buy an instrument that replaces one I already own, I usually put my old instrument for sale on consignment. I’ll wait a few months to get paid, but I’ll get paid more, and I will know exactly how much each transaction was worth. Typical consignment rates charged by stores are 15–30%. Some stores charge up to 50%—the reason is that they don’t really want to do consignment sales, because they would rather sell stock that they own. This makes business sense to them, fine, so take your consignment elsewhere. Of course you can sell your instruments directly online via Craigslist/Kijiji (Canada)/ eBay / Reverb etc. I don’t like the hassle myself, and I live in a rather remote location, so I stick with the stores that have treated me well with consignment deals.

Guitar Center has trolls at headquarters that have the heads of staff that are too generous. So, generally, if you take your guitar there, you can expect to get 50–60% of the retail value in trade, or 40–50% as a cash sale. They’ll likely nickel and dime you for every scratch so plan on the lower numbers. Of course, if it’s fugazi or doesn’t work properly, they might not notice and give you MORE than it’s worth… A private shop like Dave’s Guitar Shop in Lacrosse, WI (no affiliation except he’s a friend and I’ve bought dozens of guitars from him) will generally give you 80% of retail on a consignment, 70–75% on a trade and 60% on a sale. He’ll be honest with you about what your guitar is worth. As to the question of “making money” on buying/selling a guitar. It CAN be done, but you’ve got to know your stuff and be somewhat lucky. I’d guess I lose a bit on 1/3, break even on 1/3 and make some money on 1/3. I’ve been doing this 30 years, so I know my stuff as well as most amateurs. It’s a hobby that’s more or less paid for itself over the years, but that takes discipline and often owning a guitar for years before it’s finally worth more than you paid (OK if you love it anyway).

Okay… to be forthright, I haven’t done swapsies with a “guitar center” in decades, but I once did when I was young, so my voice counts. They gave me, on average, about 40% less than I could have got if I hadn’t needed money quickly…. I have also bought guitars “on swapsies” that I got to keep… Listen up, child, for this is a bitter lesson, but one you must learn… you will never buy a guitar for less than it’s worth or sell one for anything near what it’s worth to you. Every pawnshop in America is a testament to broken hearts and dreams. They have to feed their children just like you have to feed yours. Did you think it would happen by magic??? Did you think it was going to be easy? * * * * * * * * * *feh

They ask you which you want to do. I’ve done both. The trade in value was higher than the cash value. The cash value was low (I thought) but I didn’t want to go through consignment or online (reverb, craigslist or EBay) because of the hassle of safely boxing it up and shipping it. I’ve bought guitars through all three of those sites and was happy with them. But for selling, I just wanted to get them out and over with.

The word ‘trade’ has several meanings, including when used as a noun and as a verb. When trading a guitar, its almost always used to mean ‘exchange’. So by definition, when you say ‘trade in’ it means you’re getting another guitar (usually you add cash) for a better guitar or other equipment in trade. If you sell the guitar to the store, they will almost always give you cash. And will give you a higher value for the guitar if you want to trade it for another piece of equipment.
